title: Basic overview of Markdown potentials with R and Quarto
text:
This chapter is a simple example using R
You can import R package using the code

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


and then describe the purpose of your chapter as well as executing R command.
You can also add images
![Gentoo penguins](images/6123849122_b66af201ea_c.jpg}
For example a basic summary of a dataset is given by

df <- read.table("https://gist.githubusercontent.com/slopp/ce3b90b9168f2f921784de84fa445651/raw/4ecf3041f0ed4913e7c230758733948bc561f434/penguins.csv", sep = "," , header = TRUE)

and produce a graph

df %>% ggplot() +
    aes(x=species, y = body_mass_g) +
    geom_boxplot()  

Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite outside the scale range
(`stat_boxplot()`).









Just for curiosity, you could add an image of Gentoo penguins
You can also add images






Figure 1: Gentoo penguins



You can refer to one image using cross-reference. For example, Figure 1 is a photo of a gentoo penguin with chicks by Liam Quinn.
You can also add reference associated with models. For example, if you want to study how the body mass differ between species you should use a one way analysis of variance as described in Equation 1
\[Y_{sk} = \mu + \alpha_s + E_{sk},
\tag{1}\]
where \(s\) standes for species and \(k\) denotes each individual.
A useful citation about reproducible reserach Alston and Rick (2021)




References

Alston, Jesse M, and Jessica A Rick. 2021. “A Beginner’s Guide to Conducting Reproducible Research.” Bulletin of the Ecological Society of America 102 (2): 1–14.

title: Statistics to explore environmental questions
text:
This website is produced by the M2 MODE student during year 2025-2026 as part of their assignment in the Online Collaborative Resources course.
They were asked to produce collaboratively different illustrations on ecological data for different statistical and mathematical models.
Just click on one of the three menus on top right side of this page to visit their work. They have used up to data version control workflows to produce this website using git Github, Pull Request, Code review. A set of good practices to help them producible research in the futur.
The website is fully generated using Continuous Integration (CI) based on Github Action.

A citation Alston and Rick (2021)

title: Stats Reminder Project - Instructions
text:
Team project for groups of 3 students. Create examples demonstrating statistical/mathematical methods applied to ecological questions.
Repository: https://github.com/MarieEtienne/stats-reminder






Deliverables



Each team creates 1 example among one of the major theme:

Linear models
Differential equations

Multivariate analysis

Each student should devote time to the review process ass well
The repository will close on December 1st at 1PM and only the work merged on master will be reviewed and evaluated.
Final mark for this assignment will consider

Mastering git workflow (commit, pull push , handling conflict, Pull Request, optimmaly rebase to have a clean history)
Taking part of the reviewing process to increase global quality of the project

During the last lab on git, November 5th, students will have a test to evaluate the overall understanding of git process
The final grad will be based on both evaluation

title: Stats Reminder Project - Instructions
text:
Project requirements

Content
Each .qmd example must include:

Clear ecological question with real/realistic data
Proper cross-references: sections (@sec-methods), figures (@fig-plot), tables (@tbl-results) or equations (@eq-model)
Citations and bibliography
Well-documented code and results



Git Workflow

One branch per example: team-[names]-[method]-[description]
Update _quarto.yml to include your examples in the website structure (see Section 3.3)
Optimally Rebase before PR to ensure linear history (see Section 3.4)
PR requirements (see Section 4.2):

✅ No merge conflicts
✅ Automated checks pass
✅ One peer review
✅ At least one discussion thread

title: Stats Reminder Project - Instructions
text:
Git Workflow

Setup
# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/MarieEtienne/stats-reminder.git
cd stats-reminder

# Create team branch
git switch -b teamA
git push origin teamA


Create one branch per task
# From your team branch, create example branches
git switch teamA
git switch -b teamA-intro

# Work on your .qmd file
git add linear_model_teamA.qmd
git commit -m "Add linear model example"
....
git fetch origin teamA
git rebase teamA 

# If conflicts: resolve, then
git add <resolved-files>
git rebase --continue

# switch to team branch and update the branch with this neaw linear history
git switch teamA
git merge teamA-intro


Updating _quarto.yml
Add your examples to the website structure:
website:
  navbar:
    left:
      - text: "Team Examples"
        menu:
          - text: "Team Smith"
            menu:
              - text: "Plant Growth (Linear)"
                href: linear_model_teamA.qmd
              - text: "Predator-Prey (Diff Eq)"
                href: team-smith-diffeq-predator.qmd



Update Before PR






Warning



Always rebase on master before creating PR to ensure clean linear history and avoid conflicts.


git switch teamA
git switch -c teamA_PR #create a new branch to avoid destruction

# Fetch and rebase
git fetch origin master
git rebase origin/master

# If conflicts: resolve, then
git add <resolved-files>
git rebase --continue

# push teamA_PR and ask for PR in github, there should be no conflict
git push origin teamA_PR

title: Stats Reminder Project - Instructions
text:
Pull Requests

Creating a PR

Go to repository → Pull requests → New pull request
Base: master, Compare: teamA_PR
Write clear description (method, question, team)



PR Requirements
All must be met before merge:

✅ No conflicts (rebase if needed, see Section 3.4)
✅ Automated checks pass (builds website successfully)
✅ One review from peer/instructor
✅ One discussion thread (respond to reviewer comments)

After merge, the website automatically deploys to GitHub Pages.
Be careful that, history in teamA and teamA_PR differ, and teamA_PR is the one to be merged. So if you want to add more contents to your project, remove local and remote teamA branch (and teamA_PR once merge into master) and starts a new branch from the current master branch

title: Stats Reminder Project - Instructions
text:
Cross-References & Citations

Cross-References
## Methods {#sec-methods}

The model (@eq-linear) uses data shown in @fig-scatter and @tbl-summary.

$$ y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 x $$ {#eq-linear}

```{r}
#| label: fig-scatter
#| fig-cap: "Relationship between variables"
plot(x, y)
```

As described in @sec-methods...


Citations
Create references.bib:
@article{smith2020,
  author = {Smith, J.},
  title = {Statistical Methods},
  journal = {Ecology},
  year = {2020}
}
In your YAML:
bibliography: references.bib
In text:
According to @smith2020, the method...

title: Stats Reminder Project - Instructions
text:
Important Rules






Important




Master is protected - you cannot push directly
Use rebase not merge (see Section 3.4) as much as possible, that is the good practice
Pass all checks before requesting merge

title: Stats Reminder Project - Instructions
text:
Common Issues
Build failing: Check logs for syntax errors in .qmd, missing packages, broken cross-references, or invalid _quarto.yml.
Can’t push to master: Expected! Create a branch instead (see Section 3.2).

title: Stats Reminder Project - Instructions
text:
Checklist
Before submitting PR:

_quarto.yml updated
Cross-references used throughout
Citations included
No conflicts
Rebased on master
PR created with clear description
Checks passing
Review requested

text:

Questions? Check GitHub Issues or contact the instructor. Good luck! 🚀
